articles.title: Children in Need 2025 raises more than £45m
articles.summary: The show included appearances from Lewis Capaldi and stars of Strictly Come Dancing, The Apprentice and Gladiators.
articles.content:
Children in Need 2025 raises more than £45m

5 hours ago Share Save Annabel Rackham and Emaan Warraich Share Save

Watch all the best moments from Children in Need 2025

The 2025 Children in Need appeal has raised more than £45m to help children and young people across the UK - with the total likely to raise even further. Hosts Paddy McGuinness, Mel Giedroyc, Lenny Rush, Rochelle Humes, Vernon Kay and Big Zuu fronted the annual fundraising show on BBC One on Friday night, live from Salford. There were sketches involving stars from Gladiators and The Apprentice, as well as a performance from some of the Strictly Come Dancing professionals. Other acts included Lewis Capaldi, McFly's Tom Fletcher and his son Buzz, and Eurovision contestants Remember Monday.

The total announced at the end of the three-hour show was £45,507,536 - more than £9.5m of which was raised by Sara Cox for her 135-mile challenge. The Radio 2 DJ took part in five marathons in five days - running, jogging and walking through northern England, ending - aptly - in the town of Pudsey. Speaking to fellow Radio 2 DJ Scott Mills at the finish line on Friday afternoon, Cox said: "It's just been the maddest, most painful, wonderful thing I've ever, ever done." "I've never had shapely calves in my life," she joked, "But I have now because they are so swollen, it looks like I've been hit with a bat." She said during the appeal show: "It was like a rollercoaster... literally my mood was changing every three, four, seconds - it was a lot." Cox told the hosts she was "absolutely exhausted" but that it had been "the most amazing, painful and wonderful few days of my life".

Moment Sara Cox crosses finish line after 135-mile charity run

During The Apprentice skit, the script was flipped on Lord Sugar as he found himself on the receiving end of an intense boardroom grilling. The entrepreneur explained that he "owed a favour to Pudsey" and that was why he allowed eight children to ask questions like: "Why is your name Lord Sugar when you are so salty all the time?" "Well Sugar is my name and that's it, what can I say?" he replied.

Pudsey Bear - the yellow bear who acts as a Children in Need mascot - and actor Rush, 16, could be seen embarking on new BBC roles as "TV big cheeses" in another sketch. It showed a children's takeover that aimed to put children at the heart of all BBC programming. Rush, who wore a BBC lanyard and suit, said: "You're always going to face resistance. But remember, who runs the world? I do. Well, kids do." In another clip, Richard Madeley threatened to sack Rush, saying: "We both know what's going to happen if things don't improve, don't we? Lenny is going to be fired."

Pudsey Bear and actor Lenny Rush became the new BBC bosses

Friday night's show reimagined Gladiators - with the team of elite athletes replaced by children. The so-called "mini Gladiators" went head-to-head with contestants in a range of tasks, but there was one small snag - they were simply too tiny to take on many of the challenges properly. The live programme also saw Giedroyc and Big Zuu led in a live workout by fitness expert Joe Wicks, which also featured some of Strictly's professional dancers. Earlier in the week Big Zuu collaborated with Pudsey Bear and a group of children from a theatre project, funded by Children in Need, to present his first CBeebies Bedtime Story. He read Basil Dreams Big by Lu Fraser and Sarah Warburton, a story about resilience, bravery, and believing in yourself. It was broadcast on Thursday night and is available to stream on BBC iPlayer.

Pudsey has also taken part in a special edition of Bargain Hunt

articles.title: ILO: Strengthen Global Rules to Protect Gig Workers
articles.summary:
Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              An Instacart worker loads groceries into her car for home delivery in San Leandro, California, July 1, 2020.
                    © 2020 Ben Margot/AP Photo
          
    


  
(New York) – Governments negotiating a new global treaty on gig work should strengthen the draft text to ensure fair wages and social security for these workers and protect them from exploitative management, Human Rights Watch said today, submitting a briefing with proposals for the treaty.The International Labour Organization (ILO) is currently developing the first global rules for work organized through “digital platforms,” businesses like Uber, Lyft, or DoorDash. As part of the ILO process, governments, workers, and employers are submitting comments on the draft ahead of final negotiations in 2026.“This is a historic opportunity to make sure technology and the economy work for workers, not against them,” said Lena Simet, senior economic justice researcher at Human Rights Watch. “At the ILO, governments, employers, and workers are writing the rules together, and those rules should protect the people doing the work, not the corporations that shift costs and risks onto their workers.”The ILO estimates that platform work has nearly doubled in recent years, and the World Bank estimates that up to 400 million people now earn income through these businesses. These companies promise their workers freedom and flexibility, but in reality, undermine their rights. Around the world, platform companies misclassify workers as self-employed, evading legal obligations for minimum wages, safety, and social security. Algorithms determine who works, when, and at what rate, usually without transparency for workers or accountability for errors and injustices. Existing international law does not provide guidance on algorithmic management in the workplace, leaving a major gap in securing protections for workers’ rights. The Human Rights Watch briefing complements a joint submission with nine civil society organizations outlining concrete proposals to ensure the treaty delivers on its promise of decent work for all platform workers. Human Rights Watch’s recommendations build on findings from a report the organization released earlier in 2025, which documented that platform workers across the US are being denied their human rights, including with pay below the minimum wage, unsafe working conditions, and the use of opaque and unaccountable algorithms to evade employer responsibilities.Human Rights Watch recommends that the treaty treat platform workers as employees unless a company can prove genuine independence, ensuring workers are not wrongly classified as self-employed and denied labor rights protections. At the same time, it should make clear that all individuals working for these companies, regardless of contractual status, are entitled to the treaty’s protections.The treaty should guarantee workers’ rights to safe and healthy working conditions by requiring companies to mitigate work-related risks and algorithm-driven pressure that pushes workers to work faster or longer. It should also ensure fair wages for all working time, including waiting periods, and require companies to cover the work-related expenses and social security contributions that traditional employers pay.Stronger safeguards are also needed for algorithmic management. The treaty should require transparency about how automated systems affect all aspects of work, including pay and access to jobs, and ensure meaningful human review and appeal for automated decisions. Finally, it should explicitly protect gig workers’ rights to organize and bargain collectively without retaliation or digital surveillance, ensuring that workers can safely join together to improve their conditions.Governments should use this moment to champion a treaty that brings platform work in line with international human rights law, Human Rights Watch said.“Gig workers have the same rights as everyone else,” Simet said. “They should not be paid poverty wages or abused through the use of blackbox and unfair algorithms. This ILO treaty can help correct the violations many gig workers face worldwide and show that human rights can be enforced in the digital age.”
articles.content:
Click to expand Image An Instacart worker loads groceries into her car for home delivery in San Leandro, California, July 1, 2020. © 2020 Ben Margot/AP Photo

(New York) – Governments negotiating a new global treaty on gig work should strengthen the draft text to ensure fair wages and social security for these workers and protect them from exploitative management, Human Rights Watch said today, submitting a briefing with proposals for the treaty.

The International Labour Organization (ILO) is currently developing the first global rules for work organized through “digital platforms,” businesses like Uber, Lyft, or DoorDash. As part of the ILO process, governments, workers, and employers are submitting comments on the draft ahead of final negotiations in 2026.

“This is a historic opportunity to make sure technology and the economy work for workers, not against them,” said Lena Simet, senior economic justice researcher at Human Rights Watch. “At the ILO, governments, employers, and workers are writing the rules together, and those rules should protect the people doing the work, not the corporations that shift costs and risks onto their workers.”

The ILO estimates that platform work has nearly doubled in recent years, and the World Bank estimates that up to 400 million people now earn income through these businesses.

These companies promise their workers freedom and flexibility, but in reality, undermine their rights.

Around the world, platform companies misclassify workers as self-employed, evading legal obligations for minimum wages, safety, and social security. Algorithms determine who works, when, and at what rate, usually without transparency for workers or accountability for errors and injustices. Existing international law does not provide guidance on algorithmic management in the workplace, leaving a major gap in securing protections for workers’ rights.

The Human Rights Watch briefing complements a joint submission with nine civil society organizations outlining concrete proposals to ensure the treaty delivers on its promise of decent work for all platform workers. Human Rights Watch’s recommendations build on findings from a report the organization released earlier in 2025, which documented that platform workers across the US are being denied their human rights, including with pay below the minimum wage, unsafe working conditions, and the use of opaque and unaccountable algorithms to evade employer responsibilities.

Human Rights Watch recommends that the treaty treat platform workers as employees unless a company can prove genuine independence, ensuring workers are not wrongly classified as self-employed and denied labor rights protections. At the same time, it should make clear that all individuals working for these companies, regardless of contractual status, are entitled to the treaty’s protections.

The treaty should guarantee workers’ rights to safe and healthy working conditions by requiring companies to mitigate work-related risks and algorithm-driven pressure that pushes workers to work faster or longer. It should also ensure fair wages for all working time, including waiting periods, and require companies to cover the work-related expenses and social security contributions that traditional employers pay.

Stronger safeguards are also needed for algorithmic management. The treaty should require transparency about how automated systems affect all aspects of work, including pay and access to jobs, and ensure meaningful human review and appeal for automated decisions. Finally, it should explicitly protect gig workers’ rights to organize and bargain collectively without retaliation or digital surveillance, ensuring that workers can safely join together to improve their conditions.

Governments should use this moment to champion a treaty that brings platform work in line with international human rights law, Human Rights Watch said.

“Gig workers have the same rights as everyone else,” Simet said. “They should not be paid poverty wages or abused through the use of blackbox and unfair algorithms. This ILO treaty can help correct the violations many gig workers face worldwide and show that human rights can be enforced in the digital age.”

The article provides detailed context on the challenges faced and concrete proposals for the treaty, demonstrating substance and significance.
articles.personality_title: ILO pushes for global treaty to protect gig workers’ rights
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Gig workers are people who use apps or websites to find short jobs, like delivering food or driving passengers. Many of these workers face problems like low pay, unsafe work, and unfair treatment because current laws don’t fully protect them.

**What happened** – The International Labour Organization (ILO) is creating the first global rules to protect gig workers. Governments, workers, and employers are discussing a treaty that will set fair wages, social security, and safety standards for these workers. Human Rights Watch has shared ideas to make sure the treaty protects workers from unfair management, especially from hidden computer systems that control their work.

**Impact** – This treaty is important because millions of gig workers worldwide currently don’t have the same rights as other workers. The new rules would stop companies from calling workers “self-employed” just to avoid paying benefits or following safety laws. It also calls for clear rules about how computer programs decide work schedules and pay, so workers aren’t treated unfairly.

**What’s next step** – The treaty’s final version will be negotiated by 2026. If agreed upon, it could change how gig work is managed globally, giving workers better pay, safer jobs, and more control over their work conditions.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The ILO’s planned treaty aims to give gig workers fair pay, social protections, and rights to challenge unfair technology-based management worldwide.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’OIT promeut un traité mondial pour protéger les droits des travailleurs de la gig economy
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les travailleurs de la gig economy sont des personnes qui trouvent des petits boulots via des applications, comme livrer de la nourriture ou transporter des passagers. Beaucoup rencontrent des problèmes comme des salaires bas, des conditions dangereuses et un traitement injuste, car les lois actuelles ne les protègent pas entièrement.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – L’Organisation internationale du travail (OIT) élabore les premières règles mondiales pour protéger ces travailleurs. Gouvernements, travailleurs et employeurs discutent d’un traité qui garantira des salaires justes, une sécurité sociale et des normes de sécurité. Human Rights Watch a proposé des idées pour éviter que les travailleurs soient maltraités, notamment par des systèmes informatiques opaques qui gèrent leur travail.

**Impact** – Ce traité est important car des millions de travailleurs dans la gig economy n’ont pas les mêmes droits que les autres salariés. Les nouvelles règles empêcheront les entreprises de qualifier les travailleurs d’« indépendants » pour éviter les avantages sociaux ou les règles de sécurité. Elles demanderont aussi plus de transparence sur la façon dont les programmes informatiques décident des horaires et des salaires.

**Prochaine étape** – La version finale du traité sera négociée d’ici 2026. S’il est adopté, il pourrait transformer la gestion du travail en gig economy dans le monde, offrant aux travailleurs de meilleurs salaires, plus de sécurité et plus de contrôle sur leurs conditions de travail.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le traité prévu par l’OIT vise à garantir aux travailleurs de la gig economy des salaires justes, une protection sociale et des droits pour contester une gestion injuste basée sur la technologie.
articles.personality_title_es: OIT impulsa un tratado global para proteger los derechos de los trabajadores de la economía gig
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los trabajadores de la economía gig son personas que encuentran trabajos temporales a través de aplicaciones, como entregar comida o transportar pasajeros. Muchos enfrentan problemas como bajos salarios, condiciones inseguras y trato injusto porque las leyes actuales no los protegen completamente.

**Qué pasó** – La Organización Internacional del Trabajo (OIT) está creando las primeras reglas globales para proteger a estos trabajadores. Gobiernos, trabajadores y empleadores están discutiendo un tratado que establecerá salarios justos, seguridad social y estándares de seguridad. Human Rights Watch presentó propuestas para proteger a los trabajadores de un manejo injusto, especialmente por sistemas computarizados ocultos que controlan su trabajo.

**Impacto** – Este tratado es importante porque millones de trabajadores gig en todo el mundo no tienen los mismos derechos que otros empleados. Las nuevas reglas impedirán que las empresas clasifiquen a los trabajadores como «autónomos» para evitar pagar beneficios o cumplir con leyes de seguridad. También exigirán transparencia sobre cómo los programas informáticos deciden horarios y pagos.

**Próximo paso** – La versión final del tratado se negociará para 2026. Si se aprueba, podría cambiar cómo se gestiona el trabajo gig globalmente, dando a los trabajadores mejores salarios, trabajos más seguros y más control sobre sus condiciones.

**Resumen en una frase** – El tratado que planea la OIT busca dar a los trabajadores gig salarios justos, protección social y derechos para cuestionar la gestión injusta basada en tecnología.

articles.title: Move Over Bob: changing the trades so women don’t just join the workforce—they lead it
articles.summary:
BY THE OPTIMIST DAILY EDITORIAL TEAM Building new foundations Welcome to the third installment of The Optimist Daily’s Annual Local Changemakers series. Over five weeks, we’re celebrating ten extraordinary individuals and organizations transforming their communities through heart-led innovation. This week, we’re spotlighting changemakers who are rebuilding, physically and culturally, what has been lost, overlooked, or […]
The post Move Over Bob: changing the trades so women don’t just join the workforce—they lead it first appeared on The Optimist Daily: Making Solutions the News.
articles.content:
BY THE OPTIMIST DAILY EDITORIAL TEAM

Building new foundations

Welcome to the third installment of The Optimist Daily’s Annual Local Changemakers series. Over five weeks, we’re celebrating ten extraordinary individuals and organizations transforming their communities through heart-led innovation. This week, we’re spotlighting changemakers who are rebuilding, physically and culturally, what has been lost, overlooked, or shut out.

Today, we head to Phoenix and beyond, where the media-lifestyle brand Move Over Bob is breaking new ground in a field too long dominated by one voice by making loud room for many more.

When the story changes, the world changes

When co-founders Kate Glantz and Angie Cacace launched Move Over Bob, they weren’t just starting a magazine. They were igniting a movement.

“For too long, construction culture has centered around one story and one image of who belongs,” the brand’s Who We Are page explains. Today, women make up less than five percent of workers in some trade roles. This is not because they lack the skill or drive, but because they’ve rarely been shown that they belong. After all, how can a girl aspire to be a construction worker if she’s never seen someone like her holding the tools?

“Move Over Bob is about so much more than construction,” says Kate Glantz, co-founder and CEO. “It’s an anthem and a blueprint for women to build a full, prosperous life—and to have the (power) tools to do it on their terms.”

What began as a bold idea to print a youth-friendly trades magazine has now expanded to reach thousands of girls and young women through classrooms, libraries, youth programs, and community events. In its first year alone, 20,000 magazines were distributed across more than 400 Arizona middle and high schools, correctional facilities, nonprofits, and community centers, completely free.

Meeting the gap with tools and stories

The problem is well documented: The U.S. is facing a skilled labor shortage, with nearly two million construction jobs expected to go unfilled by 2031. But Move Over Bob saw more than a workforce issue. It saw a visibility issue.

“If a girl has never seen a female plumber, or electrician, or welder, or crane operator, how do we expect her to become one?” asks the Move Over Bob team.

That insight drives their strategy.

A lifestyle-forward print magazine blending role-model interviews, real-world training tips, and fashion-meets-function spreads.

QR-coded multimedia guides linking readers to apprenticeships, scholarships, and local training programs.

Representation at scale with contributors and stories from across experience levels, cultures, and trades.

“Build with Us”, an invitation for women in trades to share their stories, mentor, and speak at events.

Real tools, real talk

One recent highlight that Kate Glantz shared with The Optimist Daily was the winter 2026 cover shoot featuring three women welders from different backgrounds and styles, all showing up unapologetically. “I am certain thousands of our readers will find something of themselves in these role models,” Kate said. “It was the perfect combination of inspo and real talk.”

A cultural shift, not a career brochure

Unlike traditional outreach campaigns that focus solely on labor stats, Move Over Bob is building something more fundamental: a sense of belonging. They’re showing up in spaces where girls can imagine futures on their terms, in their voices.

As first-year electrical apprentice Solei Donahue shared in an early issue:

“Move Over Bob matters because it’s inspiring the next generation of girls to do things they were taught they couldn’t do.”

And it’s working. The magazine is now expanding beyond Arizona, with national subscribers and growing demand from schools, families, and workforce programs in other states.

Why Move Over Bob matters

Representation meets access:

By making tradeswomen visible and linking readers directly to opportunities, Move Over Bob turns inspiration into tangible action.

Culture change over tokenism:

This isn’t a “women can do it too” side note. It’s a redesign of the story from the inside out with men as allies and women leading the way.

Narrative as infrastructure:

The helmet, the tool belt, the ladder. These are all symbols. But so is the magazine, the quote, the cover story. Move Over Bob is building both.

The next job site: everywhere

Kate Glantz says the mission is clear: scale nationally, while staying rooted in local ecosystems. “We now have subscribers all over the country… we just need to start meeting them where labor codes and training systems are local.”

The magazine’s free distribution model remains central to their equity strategy, and partnerships with training programs and schools continue to grow.

Where others see a labor gap, Move Over Bob sees a leadership opening. And they’re handing young women the mic and the toolbox to fill it.

Hungry for more?

Go to the Move Over Bob site to learn more about their work, grab a copy of the debut magazine, and discover their merch.

Follow them on Instagram, TikTok, and Facebook for the latest updates.

articles.personality_title: Move Over Bob: empowering girls to lead in skilled trades
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Skilled trades like construction have long been dominated by men. Today, women make up less than 5% of workers in many trade jobs. This is often because girls rarely see women in these roles, making it hard to imagine themselves in those careers.

**What happened** – Move Over Bob is a new media brand started by Kate Glantz and Angie Cacace in Phoenix. It began as a magazine aimed at young people but quickly grew into a movement. The magazine shares stories of women working in trades, offers training tips, and connects readers to apprenticeships and scholarships.

**Impact** – In its first year, Move Over Bob distributed 20,000 free magazines to over 400 schools, community centers, and youth programs in Arizona. It helps girls see role models who look like them and shows that trades are a place where women can lead. This approach goes beyond numbers to create a real sense of belonging and possibility.

**What's next step** – The brand plans to expand nationally while keeping strong local partnerships. They want to reach more girls across the country with free magazines and links to local training programs. Their goal is to change the culture of trades so women don’t just join—they lead.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Move Over Bob is changing the story in skilled trades by inspiring and supporting girls to become future leaders in fields where women have been rare.
articles.personality_title_fr: Move Over Bob : encourager les filles à diriger dans les métiers spécialisés
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les métiers spécialisés comme la construction ont longtemps été dominés par les hommes. Aujourd’hui, les femmes représentent moins de 5 % des travailleurs dans de nombreux métiers. Cela vient souvent du fait que les filles voient rarement des femmes dans ces rôles, ce qui rend difficile d’imaginer leur avenir dans ces carrières.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Move Over Bob est une nouvelle marque médiatique lancée par Kate Glantz et Angie Cacace à Phoenix. Ce qui a commencé comme un magazine pour les jeunes est vite devenu un mouvement. Le magazine partage des histoires de femmes dans les métiers, donne des conseils pratiques et met en lien avec des apprentissages et des bourses.

**Impact** – En un an, Move Over Bob a distribué 20 000 magazines gratuits dans plus de 400 écoles, centres communautaires et programmes jeunesse en Arizona. Cela permet aux filles de voir des modèles qui leur ressemblent et montre que les métiers sont un endroit où les femmes peuvent prendre la tête. Cette approche dépasse les chiffres pour créer un vrai sentiment d’appartenance.

**Prochaine étape** – La marque prévoit de s’étendre à l’échelle nationale tout en gardant des partenariats locaux forts. Elle veut toucher plus de filles dans tout le pays avec des magazines gratuits et des liens vers des formations locales. Leur but est de changer la culture des métiers pour que les femmes ne se contentent pas de rejoindre le secteur, mais en deviennent leaders.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Move Over Bob change le récit dans les métiers spécialisés en inspirant et soutenant les filles pour qu’elles deviennent les futures leaders de secteurs où les femmes sont rares.
articles.personality_title_es: Move Over Bob: empoderando a las niñas para liderar en oficios especializados
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los oficios especializados como la construcción han estado dominados por hombres durante mucho tiempo. Hoy, las mujeres representan menos del 5 % de los trabajadores en muchos de estos empleos. Esto suele ser porque las niñas casi nunca ven mujeres en estos roles, lo que dificulta imaginarse en esas carreras.

**Qué pasó** – Move Over Bob es una nueva marca mediática creada por Kate Glantz y Angie Cacace en Phoenix. Comenzó como una revista para jóvenes pero pronto se convirtió en un movimiento. La revista comparte historias de mujeres en oficios, ofrece consejos prácticos y conecta a las lectoras con aprendizajes y becas.

**Impacto** – En su primer año, Move Over Bob distribuyó 20,000 revistas gratuitas en más de 400 escuelas, centros comunitarios y programas juveniles en Arizona. Ayuda a las niñas a ver modelos a seguir que se parecen a ellas y demuestra que los oficios son un lugar donde las mujeres pueden liderar. Este enfoque va más allá de los números para crear un sentido real de pertenencia.

**Próximo paso** – La marca planea expandirse a nivel nacional manteniendo fuertes alianzas locales. Quiere llegar a más niñas en todo el país con revistas gratuitas y enlaces a programas de formación locales. Su objetivo es cambiar la cultura de los oficios para que las mujeres no solo se unan, sino que lideren.

**Resumen en una frase** – Move Over Bob está cambiando la historia en los oficios especializados al inspirar y apoyar a las niñas para que sean las futuras líderes en campos donde las mujeres han sido pocas.

articles.content:
Waorani Indigenous leaders protest in front of the Constitutional Court in Quito on August 20, 2025, two years after a key victory for climate democracy in an Indigenous-led referendum to halt exploitation of an oil block in Yasuni National Park.

© 2025 Rodrigo Buendia/AFP via Getty Images
articles.reasoning: The article highlights Indigenous leaders actively enforcing a referendum that protects their land and environment from oil exploitation, representing a significant victory for Indigenous rights and environmental protection with broad societal impact.
articles.personality_title: Ecuadorian Indigenous Leaders Push to Enforce Oil Ban in Yasuni Park
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In 2023, Indigenous communities in Ecuador held a referendum to stop oil drilling in Yasuni National Park, a large and important rainforest in the Amazon. This vote was a major step to protect their land and the environment.

**What happened** – On August 20, 2025, Waorani Indigenous leaders gathered in Quito, Ecuador’s capital, to protest in front of the Constitutional Court. They demanded that the court enforce the results of the referendum, which legally bans oil companies from drilling in the protected area.

**Impact** – This action shows Indigenous people taking a strong stand to protect their land and rights. It also helps preserve one of the most biodiverse places on Earth, which is important for wildlife and climate. The case highlights how Indigenous voices can influence national laws and environmental decisions.

**What's next step** – The Constitutional Court will review the case and decide whether to fully enforce the referendum. If enforced, it could stop future oil exploration in Yasuni and inspire other countries to respect Indigenous votes on environmental issues.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Indigenous leaders in Ecuador are actively working to make sure a vote to protect their Amazon land from oil drilling is respected by the courts.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les leaders autochtones équatoriens exigent l’application de l’interdiction de forage pétrolier dans le parc Yasuni
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En 2023, les communautés autochtones d’Équateur ont organisé un référendum pour arrêter le forage pétrolier dans le parc national Yasuni, une grande forêt amazonienne importante. Ce vote était une étape majeure pour protéger leurs terres et l’environnement.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 20 août 2025, les leaders waorani autochtones se sont rassemblés à Quito, la capitale de l’Équateur, pour protester devant la Cour constitutionnelle. Ils ont demandé que la cour fasse appliquer les résultats du référendum, qui interdit légalement aux compagnies pétrolières de forer dans cette zone protégée.

**Impact** – Cette action montre que les peuples autochtones défendent fermement leurs terres et leurs droits. Elle aide aussi à préserver l’un des endroits les plus riches en biodiversité au monde, important pour la faune et le climat. Ce cas montre comment les voix autochtones peuvent influencer les lois nationales et les décisions environnementales.

**Prochaine étape** – La Cour constitutionnelle va examiner le dossier et décider si elle applique pleinement le référendum. Si c’est le cas, cela pourrait arrêter l’exploration pétrolière future dans Yasuni et inspirer d’autres pays à respecter les votes autochtones sur les questions environnementales.

**Phrase clé** – Les leaders autochtones en Équateur travaillent activement pour que leur vote protégeant leur terre amazonienne contre le forage pétrolier soit respecté par la justice.
articles.personality_title_es: Líderes indígenas ecuatorianos exigen hacer cumplir la prohibición de petróleo en el parque Yasuni
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En 2023, las comunidades indígenas de Ecuador realizaron un referéndum para detener la extracción de petróleo en el parque nacional Yasuni, una gran y valiosa selva amazónica. Esta votación fue un paso importante para proteger sus tierras y el medio ambiente.

**Qué pasó** – El 20 de agosto de 2025, líderes indígenas Waorani se reunieron en Quito, la capital de Ecuador, para protestar frente a la Corte Constitucional. Exigieron que la corte haga cumplir los resultados del referéndum, que prohíbe legalmente que las compañías petroleras exploren en esta área protegida.

**Impacto** – Esta acción muestra que los pueblos indígenas defienden con fuerza sus tierras y derechos. También ayuda a preservar uno de los lugares con mayor biodiversidad del mundo, importante para los animales y el clima. El caso destaca cómo las voces indígenas pueden influir en las leyes nacionales y decisiones ambientales.

**Próximo paso** – La Corte Constitucional revisará el caso y decidirá si hace cumplir completamente el referéndum. Si se aplica, podría detener futuras exploraciones petroleras en Yasuni e inspirar a otros países a respetar los votos indígenas sobre temas ambientales.

**Frase clave** – Los líderes indígenas en Ecuador trabajan activamente para que se respete en la justicia su voto que protege sus tierras amazónicas de la extracción de petróleo.
